topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d666696368727828100200#post_54d666696368727828100200
Things that are coming out in the next ten years that will each individually cause massive cultural paradigm shifts:
Solar roadways.
Synthesized food.
Biomechatronics being able to function better than organic limbs.
Self driving cars.
3D printed houses.
3D printed products.
3D printed organs.
Brain enhancements.
Medical nanotechnology.
Cryostasis.
Widespread adoption of computer chips that simulate brain cells.
Brain-machine interfaces.
Virtual Reality.
Autonomous surgery robots.
Private space tourism.
Algae biofuel.
Spinal cord bridges (basically curing paralysis).
Quantum computing is already here, but only the big tech firms use it cause of costs.
Blue brain project.


I don't think twenty years from now cultures of developed countries will not bear any resemblance to how they currently look because if you have twenty technologies come out that all individually would cause a paradigm shift then that's a pretty big change.  To use an analogy if you take a broom and replace out the brush and replace out the handle and replace out everything is it the same broom?  No, but you can still sweep the floor with it.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d6689463687204b4ab0f00#post_54d6689463687204b4ab0f00
Still have to be cautious of the consequences though. Like find ways to deal with unintended negative effects of these things since we're heading into unknown territories with this. Other wise, it'll just be plain foolishness on humanity's part that may potentially drive us to our doom as a species and everything around us.

Many cultures, elements and customs may still be preserved. Even if they are not as mainstream anymore. Depending on how they adapt to the new environment.

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d6745c6368720a2e5d2700#post_54d6745c6368720a2e5d2700
Oh no; I totally agree that there's dangers and that people that worry about say deflation are totally right, I just don't give a shit because on the macro scale often times there's hard decisions of if you want 100000 people to keep their well paying jobs or lift 200000 people out of poverty.

Take 3D printed houses; 3D printed buildings are already being worked on, but when it reaches widespread adoption it's going to cause a housing crash due to rapid devaluing of people's houses.  Your choice in that situation is to not have 3D printed houses and save tens of millions of people's mortgages and have them continue living in their houses *OR* have 3D printed houses and tens of millions of people's mortgages just evaporate overnight forcing them to sell their houses and move to the new nice houses; which is better 20 million people still keeping their homes or 200 million people having drastically lower rent and/or drastically lower cost housing?

Take 3D printed organs, biomechatronics, repairing spinal damage, cryostasis and surgery robots; your choice is to in the long run keep millions of jobs intact or save hundreds of millions of lives through better medical treatment.

Ghost in the Shell: Stand Alone complex actually had a episode about this where a girl received a heart transplant from the black market from med students that took organs from people receiving cybernetics that would have normally been discarded because there was such pressure for everyone to receive cybernetics that if you didn't want to be a cyborg your only choices were to pay a insanely large bill to get a new organ that you couldn't realistically ever pay off in your lifetime/go to the black market or die.


Do I think that's morally wrong?  No, cause every time there's a new technological advancement *SOMEONE* is going to lose their job.

Hell even my current job will probably last only 1-2 years because the print industry has taken a huge crap.  That's why I'm still going to go to school because my current job is rapidly becoming technologically obsolete.  Do I go around going "fuck you internet!  You took muh job!"; no cause that's just a side effect of technological advancement; often times the job market rapidly changes.  If anything I support technological advancement because the average wages of people worldwide taking into account inflation/deflation of their countries has gone drastically up and the quality of living worldwide on average is going up; sure the world is shitty, but it's becoming less shitty over time.
topics.author: 38b55cdf63616403d7560600

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d67fb863687251b1a82100#post_54d67fb863687251b1a82100
3D printed houses are something I completely would like. Housing should be a right. Yeah, I can see that the 3D printed organs having a potential to end the black market trade of illegally harvested organs. And possibly the end of the need of someone having to forfeit their body parts.
But the nanobots.... what if they go awry? Maybe I've been watching too many sci-fi stuff, but still...

I still think there needs to be plans that aim to mitigate unemployment. Because things can get pretty ugly when people are pushed out of their jobs and are unable to get another forcing them to live in poverty. Heck, even university graduates have it hard when it comes to finding good jobs this day and age due to there simply being not enough jobs on the market. Not all people are built to be high skilled either. If I was a leader, I'd probably be the type who'd try to put the welfare of the people above unchecked progress if I have to. Maybe humanity has  progressed a little too far than we were intended to be. I think, the world is good as it is, despite the existing flaws. You solve one familiar flaw, you create more unfamiliar ones.

I'm all for.
-Virtual Reality.
-Algae biofuel
-Memory enhancement

I'm curious about the synthetic foods though, even though I'm a traditionalist when it comes to food.

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d6833163687207417c0400#post_54d6833163687207417c0400
[bq="SeraphimDawn"]"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d67fb863687251b1a82100#post_54d67fb863687251b1a82100

I'm curious about the synthetic foods though, even though I'm a traditionalist when it comes to food.[/bq]
Synthesized food would end world hunger cause you would no longer need farms or ranches instead the food could be grown in local labs meaning you could make food that comes from plants that only grow in certain parts of the world anywhere with a lab.

Also the main cause of deforestation is to make way for ranches so that would also cause worldwide reforestation.

Downside: ranchers, farmers and such would be out of jobs.

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d684ab63687221600f0400#post_54d684ab63687221600f0400
I hope they taste good. And not Soylent Green. *And protected from malicious tampering.* I don't want any shady government/corporate/organization agendas involved in their productions. The only way to combat this is to allow the public transparency to know what goes in their food, public should have that right.
We already have scientists developing petri-dish burgers grown from stem cells.
Synthetic food might also reduce the need for land to produce food. But that may put farmers out of their jobs...

"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/54d689dd6368723b600e1d00#post_54d689dd6368723b600e1d00
Exactly; everything ever that ever betters the world also causes some people to lose their jobs.  When synthesized food reaches widespread adoption you're talking about billions of people no longer having to go hungry *BUT* you're also talking about putting tens of millions of people out of jobs.
